image.altText: A blue flame emitting from a gas burner on a stove top

items.synopsis: The Victorian government will ban gas connections to new homes and residential subdivisions from January 1 next year.

title.children: Victoria bans gas connections in new homes from 2024

image.altText: Caboolture plane crash

items.synopsis: A man and a woman have died after a collision between two aircraft at Caboolture Airfield.

title.children: Investigation launched after mid-air collision leaves two dead north of Brisbane

image.altText: Girl in silhouette watches sunset from rocks

items.synopsis: The United Nations secretary-general delivers a dramatic speech warning the heatwaves searing much of the northern hemisphere have been a "disaster" for the planet. An emerging El Niño means it may be just the start.

title.children: United Nations warns of 'global boiling' as July set to shatter heat records

image.altText: Daniel Andrews makes a hand gesture at a press conference. He is outdoors

items.synopsis: Daniel Andrews has used the controversy surrounding IBAC's latest report to take power away from local councils and into government hands, writes Richard Willingham.

title.children: Victoria's premier doesn't waste an opportunity — he has used IBAC's latest report to strengthen government power

image.altText: An SES rescue boat with three crew traverse floods in Maribyrnong, Melbourne.

items.synopsis: Melbourne Water discussed "tweaking" the parameters of the Maribyrnong River flood review based on input from its insurer, documents reveal

title.children: Melbourne Water consulted insurer, government on independent flood review, documents reveal

image.altText: A composite image of two Australian players looking determined, and one Nigerian player looking triumphant.

items.synopsis: Australia's loss to Nigeria sets up a must-win clash against Canada in Melbourne on Monday — these are the five things we learned from the day of play.

title.children: Five quick hits — Matildas face do-or-die clash against Canada as Australia fails to capitalise on early dominance

image.altText: A soccer player wearing yellow and green sits on her haunches after a game

items.synopsis: The Matildas dominated Nigeria in almost every category, but what does it matter when they lost the only one that counts, writes Sam Lewis.

title.children: Should the Matildas' loss to Nigeria be a reality check?

image.altText: Composite image of two women and a man.

items.synopsis: Awareness of the Voice is low among newly arrived migrant and refugee communities, a survey by settlement service AMES Australia finds.

title.children: 'This is their country': Migrants say they need more resources to learn about the Voice to Parliament

image.altText: A row of heavily armed men in camo gear, carrying guns

items.synopsis: Yevgeny Prigozhin's attempted mutiny last month might have failed in Russia, but in Mali and a handful of other African nations, the Wagner Group's influence — and reign of terror — is expanding.

title.children: In a remote African town, armed men with Russian accents suddenly arrived. Putin's enemy sent them

image.altText: Abbott gestures whilst talking wearing a black suit and dark blue tie on a committee bench inside parliament.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Tony Abbott claims the National Indigenous Australians Agency disburses $30b a year on Indigenous programs. Is that correct?

title.children: We fact checked Tony Abbott on his claim $30b is spent per year by the NIAA. Here's what we found

image.altText: Josh hazlewood, in Australian cricket gear, clenches his fists and cheers in celebration in front of the stumps.

items.synopsis: This fifth Ashes Test at The Oval is no dead rubber, as every subplot and story that has made this series great comes to a head with the history and future of the game seemingly on the line, Dean Bilton writes.

title.children: The Ashes may be settled, but the battle for the narrative is just getting started

image.altText: A graphic image shows the Metricon logo in front of a house

items.synopsis: More than 60 complaints have been lodged with NSW Fair Trading since March, with Metricon listed on the regulator's complaints register for the last four consecutive months.

title.children: Investigation launched into Australia's top home builder Metricon, as more complaints emerge

image.altText: An overhead shot of university students sitting in a lecture theatre.

items.synopsis: Universities have told a Senate inquiry it is not "feasible" to attempt to detect AI cheats, instead saying the sector will have to overhaul its entire approach to teaching to ensure students actually learn what they are meant to.

title.children: Universities say AI cheats can't be beaten, moving away from attempts to block AI

image.altText: A smiling man in a suit and tie

items.synopsis: Lawyers for war veteran Heston Russell accuse the ABC of engaging in an "inexcusable abuse of power" by publishing "false articles" before using a "PR machine" to defend the journalism.

title.children: ABC accused of engaging in 'inexcusable abuse of power' by publishing 'false articles' about war veteran

image.altText: Sam Kerr looks to her left as she watches the Matildas warm up for their World Cup match against Nigeria.

items.synopsis: The Matildas are still no closer to knowing whether Sam Kerr will be available to face Canada in their crucial final group match, as their World Cup campaign hangs in the balance following the loss to Nigeria.

title.children: Matildas on a knife-edge as they hope for Sam Kerr's World Cup return against Canada

image.altText: An image of Sydney's CBD, with people walking, faces not visible, carrying shopping bags.

items.synopsis: The US economy has grown at a faster rate than economists predicted, warding off concerns it may fall into a recession this year, while Australian investors await retail sales data ahead of next week's RBA meeting. Follow live.

title.children: Retail spending fall 'likely ensures' RBA will leave interest rates on hold, US fights off recession fears, ASX lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has shed 1% to 7,378 points as of 1:25pm AEST, but still looks on track to finish the week higher. All sectors are firmly in the red, with the exception of energy which has picked up a modest 0.1%. Real estate has shed the most, down 2.4%, while basic materials are down 1.9%, and industrials have dipped by 1.1%. And while the ASX is sinking at the moment, it remains on track to finish higher for the week and is still in with a shot of closing up by 1.1% — which would make it the third straight week it's gained. As for the top five movers : Insignia Financial +2.4% BlueScope Steel +1.1% Megaport +1% Chorus +1% Breville +0.9% And the bottom five movers : Capricorn Metals -10.1% Regis Resources -8% Perpetual -7.9% Perseus Mining -6.9% West African Resources -6.7%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX sinks but remains on track to finish higher for the week

children.content: The local share market has
shed 1% to 7,378 points
as of 1:25pm AEST, but still looks on track to finish the week higher.
All sectors are firmly in the red, with the exception of energy which has picked up a modest 0.1%.
Real estate has shed the most, down 2.4%, while basic materials are down 1.9%, and industrials have dipped by 1.1%.
And while the ASX is sinking at the moment, it remains on track to finish higher for the week and is

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Although some economists are firmly in team "cause for pause" after today's data, others are less convinced. Westpac's outgoing chief economist Bill Evans maintains his view that the RBA will raise the cash rate again by 0.25 percentage points next week — despite the weaker retail sales figures. He notes that the RBA will be "guarded" on the inflation data for the June quarter, and expects they will use that more detailed data to closely examine underlying, sticky inflation, the labour market, and productivity. "If, as we consider likely, the RBA’s revised forecasts show little progress in this regard then the board should take out more 'insurance' with an additional 25bp rate hike at its August meeting," he wrote. "A combination of one last hike in August complemented with the ongoing 'soft' tightening bias seems to be the best approach to a difficult challenge." That's also the view of the Commonwealth Bank, who also expect another 0.25 percentage point hike next week — but that it will be the last one the RBA will deliver this cycle. Senior economist Belinda Allen said, on balance, there were enough areas of concern. including rent and services inflation, the lack of wages data, and labour market data to convince the RBA to lift once more. "Overall there is enough evidence to suggest the path of least regret for the RBA is  to lift the cash rate by 25bp to 4.35% in August ," she said. "This should provide an offset to  any lingering risks in the inflation and wages outlook. "We expect this to be the last rate hike of this cycle and for the RBA to be on hold  until 2024, when a new schedule of board meetings is introduced. "Currently we  have the first rate cut in February, but the clear risk is a later start date to the easing  cycle, and less cuts in 2024 given the resilient labour market."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Not everyone is convinced of an RBA rate pause on Tuesday

children.content: Although some economists are firmly in team "cause for pause" after today's data, others are less convinced.
Westpac's outgoing chief economist
Bill Evans
maintains his view that the
RBA will raise the cash rate again by 0.25 percentage points next week
— despite the weaker retail sales figures.

He notes that the RBA will be "guarded" on the inflation data for the June quarter, and expects they will use that more detailed data to closely examine underlying, sticky inflation, the labour market, and productivity.
"If, as we consider likely, the RBA’s revised forecasts show little progress in this regard then the board should
take out more 'insurance' with an additional 25bp rate hike
at its August meeting," he wrote.
"A combination of one last hike in August complemented with the ongoing 'soft' tightening bias seems to be the best approach to a difficult challenge."
That's also the view of the
Commonwealth Bank, who also expect another 0.25 percentage point hike next week
— but that it will be the last one the RBA will deliver this cycle.
Senior economist
Belinda Allen
said, on balance, there were enough areas of concern. including rent and services inflation, the lack of wages data, and labour market data to convince the RBA to lift once more.
"Overall there is enough evidence to suggest the path of least regret for the RBA is  to
lift the cash rate by 25bp to 4.35% in August
," she said.
"This should provide an
offset to  any lingering risks in the inflation
and wages outlook.
"We expect this to be the
last rate hike of this cycle
and for the RBA to be on hold  until 2024, when a new schedule of board meetings is introduced.
"Currently we  have the
first rate cut in February, but the clear risk is a later start date to the easing  cycle
, and less cuts in 2024 given the resilient labour market."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: According to some early analysis, the figures are certainly adding to the cause for a rate pause. IFM Investors chief economist Alex Joiner says the figures released by the ABS today are enough to "add to the pause case" for the RBA. "And there it is, very weak nominal retail sales in June, particularly weak across durable retail, department stores back sharply," he wrote on Twitter. "This is related to discounting activity as well as weaker volumes but add to the pause case for the RBA nonetheless." Market analyst Tony Sycamore from IG says the figures are a "sure sign" that rates are impacting households, and suggests the cash rate will remain on hold when looking at the broader economic data from the past week. "Following a downside surprise in inflation on Wednesday, the market was eagerly awaiting the release of Retail Sales data this morning, the final piece of the RBA jigsaw puzzle before Tuesday's board meeting," he said. "Today's numbers provide a sure sign that higher interest rates are impacting household spending patterns and will likely ensure the RBA keeps its cash rate on hold at 4.1% at next week's board meeting."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is the RBA likely to leave rates on hold next week?

children.content: According to some early analysis, the figures are certainly adding to the cause for a rate pause.
IFM Investors chief economist Alex Joiner
says the figures released by the ABS today are enough to "add to the pause case" for the RBA.
"And there it is, very weak nominal retail sales in June, particularly weak across durable retail, department stores back sharply," he wrote on Twitter.
"This is related to discounting activity as well as weaker volumes but add to the pause case for the RBA nonetheless."
Market analyst
Tony Sycamore from IG
says the figures are a "sure sign" that rates are impacting households, and
suggests the cash rate will remain on hold
when looking at the broader economic data from the past week.

"Following a downside surprise in inflation on Wednesday, the market was eagerly awaiting the release of Retail Sales data this morning, the final piece of the RBA jigsaw puzzle before Tuesday's board meeting," he said.
"Today's numbers provide a sure sign that
higher interest rates are impacting household spending patterns
and will
likely ensure the RBA keeps its cash rate on hold at 4.1%
at next week's board meeting."

image.altText: A man in a hair salon chair holds up dreadlocks that have been cut off.

items.synopsis: Christopher Mark Jordan, 36, appears in a Launceston court accused of murdering a Tasmanian teen after the discovery of human remains in bushland this week.

title.children: Man accused of murdering teen Shyanne-Lee Tatnell named in first court appearance

image.altText: Australian Financial Complaints authority ombudsman David Locke.

items.synopsis: The financial ombudsman has experienced a record rise in complaints as Australians voice their anger at scams, slow insurer claims handling, and buy-now-pay-later products.

title.children: Delays in insurer claims handling and financial scams drive record rise in complaints to financial ombudsman

image.altText: A close up shot of Daniel Andrews face during a media conference.

items.synopsis: A proposal to host a regional Commonwealth Games at almost half the cost of the eventual government plan was provided to senior bureaucrats in 2021.

title.children: Victorian government ignored plan to host a cheaper Commonwealth Games

image.altText: man holding large spider

items.synopsis: Australia Post is trying to stop online retailers from shipping live bugs across the country in the mail after researchers raised biosecurity and conservation concerns.

title.children: The most popular bugs sold online hint at a sub-culture that's now under threat

image.altText: Anthony Albanese holds up his ballot while voting in the election that makes him the prime minister

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will further escalate a high-stakes political stand-off with the Greens, in a move that could send Australians to an early, double-dissolution election.

title.children: PM stepping closer to early election trigger as housing battle with Greens escalates

image.altText: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in a blue collared shirt and Akubra hat, standing outside and looking down.

items.synopsis: A report from the Productivity Commission has exposed – without spelling it out – an odd shortcoming in the Albanese government's sales pitch for its Voice proposal, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: This week we saw an odd shortcoming in Albanese's sales pitch for the Voice

image.altText: A girl sitting in a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Eileen's heart used to beat through her chest due to a rare medical condition. A lung transplant gave her a second chance, and her family would like to see more people register as organ donors.

title.children: In 12 hours, Eileen was taken from a Sydney hospital ward to Melbourne and had a new set of lungs

image.altText: Woman with shaved head in floral dress sings into microphone

items.synopsis: From the moment she rocketed to international stardom with her rendition of Prince's Nothing Compares 2 U, Sinéad O'Connor attracted plenty of public attention.

title.children: Ripping the pope, torching Madonna: The many controversies of Sinéad O'Connor's career

image.altText: A man with long wearing a white sweater playing a guitar and singing into a microphone with a dark background

items.synopsis: He was a founding member of the iconic American band known for favourites such as Take It to the Limit, Take It Easy and The Best of My Love.

title.children: Eagles bassist Randy Meisner dies aged 77

image.altText: Aerial view of the Port Arthur historic site, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: A research paper finds World Heritage sites, protected for their unique natural or cultural values, are under extreme threat from climate change and risk being de-listed if those values are eroded.

title.children: 'Water is getting into these buildings': Sea level rises are hurting our World Heritage sites, research finds

image.altText: A partially overturned boat washed up on the bank of a body of water.

items.synopsis: Typhoon Doksuri regains super typhoon strength in its final approach to south-eastern China after pummelling Taiwan and the northern Philippines with rain and strong winds that led to the capsize of a ferry in which at least 26 people died.

title.children: Super typhoon heads towards China after ferry capsize kills at least 26 in Philippines

image.altText: Zainab shown from the side, her hijab is in view and she's looking at the shrines.

items.synopsis: Each year, millions of Shiite Muslims flock to Karbala in Iraq to mourn Imam Hussein. So what does Ashura mean to them?

title.children: 'Bringing people to tears shows how human they are': Why millions weep at this massive pilgrimage

image.altText: A woman in Islamic headscarf stands at a window with her back to the camera

items.synopsis: When Berivan was freed from ISIS captivity she faced a terrible choice: leave her homeland forever or abandon her daughter. Now she hopes Australia will come to the rescue, writes Stephanie March.

title.children: Berivan faced a terrible choice – to win her freedom she had to abandon her daughter

image.altText: a woman smiles into the distance next to a cane field

items.synopsis: For a long time, the eldest son has been seen as the natural successor to a family farm. But there is change on the horizon.

title.children: 'Succession is a real life drama': Are the patriarchal tides turning for farm daughters?

image.altText: Middle aged man close up of his face in a car, photographer in background

items.synopsis: Lawyers for Tim Mathieson, the former partner of Julia Gillard, say he will plead guilty to a charge of sexual assault during a hearing in the Melbourne Magistrates' Court.

title.children: Tim Mathieson, former partner of Julia Gillard, to plead guilty to sexual assault charge

image.altText: A woman with her arms folded stands against a tree.

items.synopsis: Documents show the Yarrabah Aboriginal Shire Council raised concerns with the state government over critical infrastructure failures more than a year before lead was discovered in the community's tap water.

title.children: Answers wanted over cause of lead leaching into drinking water

image.altText: Sinead O'connor wearing a priests black outfit with a cross holding a microphone and smiling

items.synopsis: Police say singer Sinéad O'Connor was found unresponsive at an address in London and pronounced dead at the scene.

title.children: Sinéad O'Connor was found unresponsive at London address, police say death is not being treated as suspicious

image.altText: Dan Bell loooks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Dan Bell will never forget the day he had to help save the life of a colleague who'd been stabbed by a patient at Tasmania's North West Regional Hospital. It made him question his future as an emergency department nurse.

title.children: Dan has been punched, spat on and threatened while at work in the ED. He's desperate for change

image.altText: Lloyd Austin and Rchard Marle at a press conference.

items.synopsis: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin and Secretary of State Antony Blinken are here for meetings with their counterparts ahead of joint AUSMIN talks that are likely to feature climate change, regional geopolitics, AUKUS and expanding defence ties between Australia and the United States.

title.children: US defense secretary accuses China of 'bullying behaviour' ahead of high-level talks in Brisbane
